metatags.citation_author_institution: School of Automobile and Transportation, Xihua University, Chengdu, 610039, China
metatags.citation_abstract:
Abstract

This paper develops a convex programming (CP) framework for optimal sizing and energy management of smart home with battery energy storage system (BESS) and photovoltaic (PV) power generation, for the goal of maximizing home economy, while satisfying home power demand. We analyse the historical electric energy data of three different homes located in California and Texas, and indicate the necessity and importance of a BESS. Based on the s

metatags.citation_title: Conditional value-at-risk model for smart home energy management systems
metatags.citation_author_institution: Institute for Systems and Computer Engineering, Technology and Science (INESCTEC), 4200-465 Porto, Portugal
metatags.citation_reference: citation_journal_title=Energy;citation_author=M.S. Javadi;citation_author=M. Gough;citation_author=M. Lotfi;citation_author=A. Esmaeel Nezhad;citation_author=S.F. Santos;citation_author=J.P.S. Catalão;citation_title=Optimal self-scheduling of home energy management system in the presence of photovoltaic power generation and batteries;citation_pages=118568;citation_volume=210;citation_publication_date=2020;citation_doi=10.1016/j.energy.2020.118568;
metatags.citation_journal_title: e-Prime - Advances in Electrical Engineering, Electronics and Energy
metatags.citation_abstract:
Abstract

This paper presents a self-scheduling framework, using a risk-constrained optimization model for the home energy management system (HEMS), considering fixed, controllable, and interruptible loads, as a new contribution to earlier studies. The objectives are reducing the electricity bill and managing the risk of purchasing energy over on-peak hours and prosumer's discomfort index (DI) due to shifting load to undesired hours. In this regard, the problem formulation is represented as a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) model. Afterward, the proposed HEMS is promoted to a conditional value-at-risk (CVaR) model. The prosumer is equipped with an energy storage system and a solar photovoltaic (PV) panel. A substantial fraction of the load demand is controllable, and there is an inverter-based he
metatags.og:title: Conditional value-at-risk model for smart home energy management systems

metatags.citation_title: Performance analysis of different control models for smart demand–supply energy management system
metatags.citation_author_institution: Research Institute for Sciences and Engineering (RISE), University of Sharjah, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates
metatags.citation_reference: citation_journal_title=Renew. Sustain. Energy Rev.;citation_author=N.T. Mbungu;citation_title=Control and estimation techniques applied to smart microgrids: A review;citation_pages=113251;citation_publication_date=2023;
metatags.citation_abstract:
Abstract

Several features of innovative grid technologies can be deployed to improve the overall performance of the power system environment. This can be seen from the generation to the consumption of energy. The two-way communication of smart metering introduces the novel functionalities of the energy management system. This paper presents a practical implementation of using the intelligent metering system. It consists of implementing a nanogrid that optimally coordinates the energy from the solar panel, battery storage and utility grid to supply the end user. The developed model is validated with an optimal value of the state of charge of the distributed energy storage to maximise energy from the solar panel and battery storage while minimising the power received from the utility grid. A demand response scheme

metatags.citation_title: Distributed Learning Applications in Power Systems: A Review of Methods, Gaps, and Challenges
metatags.title: Distributed Learning Applications in Power Systems: A Review of Methods, Gaps, and Challenges
metatags.dc.creator: Nastaran Gholizadeh
metatags.dc.description: In recent years, machine learning methods have found numerous applications in power systems for load forecasting, voltage control, power quality monitoring, anomaly detection, etc. Distributed learning is a subfield of machine learning and a descendant of the multi-agent systems field. Distributed learning is a collaboratively decentralized machine learning algorithm designed to handle large data sizes, solve complex learning problems, and increase privacy. Moreover, it can reduce the risk of a single point of failure compared to fully centralized approaches and lower the bandwidth and central storage requirements. This paper introduces three existing distributed learning frameworks and reviews the applications that have been proposed for them in power systems so far. It summarizes the methods, benefits, and challenges of distributed learning frameworks in power systems and identifies the gaps in the literature for future studies.
metatags.dc.title: Distributed Learning Applications in Power Systems: A Review of Methods, Gaps, and Challenges
metatags.dc.subject: machine learning

scholarlyarticle.name: Distributed Learning Applications in Power Systems: A Review of Methods, Gaps, and Challenges

metatags.creator: LaTeX with hyperref
metatags.author: Nemanja Mišljenović, Matej Žnidarec, Goran Knežević, Damir Šljivac and Andreas Sumper
metatags.subject: This review provides the state of the art of energy management systems (EMS) and organizational structures of prosumers. Integration of renewable energy sources (RES) into the household brings new challenges in optimal operation, power quality, participation in the electricity market and power system stability. A common solution to these challenges is to develop an EMS with different prosumer organizational structures. EMS development is a multidisciplinary process that needs to involve several aspects of observation. This paper provides an overview of the prosumer organizational and control structures, types and elements, prediction methods of input parameters, optimization frameworks, optimization methods, objective functions, constraints and the market environment. Special attention is given to the optimization framework and prediction of input parameters, which represents room for improvement, that mitigate the impact of uncertainties associated with RES-based generation, consumption and market prices on
metatags.title: A Review of Energy Management Systems and Organizational Structures of Prosumers
